item.title: Family / Origin of the Beginning
item.description: Portrayed in this piece is a room with 5 persons sitting at a table. These persons are Levi van Veluw, his father, mother, brother and sister. The room is executed as a life-size installation (4m x 2.5m x 2.5m) in which everything , including the family members themselves, is covered with 20.000 dark brown wooden blocks. (without any digital manipulation) At first glance everyone is sitting peacefully at the table, the picture of a perfect family unit. Yet this group of figures is positioned in an abstract environment, unrecognisable and therefore far removed from reality. Dimly light and dark in colour the overriding tone of this work is claustrophobic and sombre, exuding a sense of loneliness. The awkward silence and dark colour suggest uncomfortable underlying tensions and emotions. The endless repetition of wooden blocks stands for van Veluws attempts to gain control of his own position within the familial structure.
item.content:encoded: Portrayed in this piece is a room with 5 persons sitting at a table. These persons are Levi van Veluw, his father, mother, brother and sister. The room is executed as a life-size installation (4m x 2.5m x 2.5m) in which everything , including the family members themselves, is covered with 20.000 dark brown wooden blocks. (without any digital manipulation) At first glance everyone is sitting peacefully at the table, the picture of a perfect family unit. Yet this group of figures is positioned in an abstract environment, unrecognisable and therefore far removed from reality. Dimly light and dark in colour the overriding tone of this work is claustrophobic and sombre, exuding a sense of loneliness. The awkward silence and dark colour suggest uncomfortable underlying tensions and emotions. The endless repetition of wooden blocks stands for van Veluws attempts to gain control of his own position within the familial structure.

item.title: Lomography - Japan Golden Week Cameras
item.description: When conceived, these cameras were meant to commemorate Japan's Golden Week, a time for celebrating Japanese culture and taking a well-earned rest from work. After the natural disasters of 2011, the cameras were taken on a whole new meaning; they became a way to help the community to recover from the damages caused by the earthquake and tsunami. With the purchase of a camera, you were contributing to the donation of EUR 20,000 to the Red Cross Relief Japan campaign. The inspiration for this edition were the Japanese tenuguis and vintage Kimonos. Taking their craftsmanship approach and immaculate textile print design, we chose a calm and light color to celebrate the welcoming of the spring. The graphics covering the camera bodies, were printed with metallic Pantone on natural raw canvas. We used the same fabric to bind the books and the same metallic tones for the front/end book papers. The Diana Mini "Jiyu" symbolizes freedom and has a delicate charm with its floral design and clean colours. It uses 35mm film and produces beautiful square or half-frame photos. The Diana F+ "Kirameki" sparkles with its intricate design and calming colours. This medium-format camera promises dreamy square photos and unlimited creative options when paired with Diana accessories. The Fisheye 2 "Shiawase" symbolizes the spreading of happiness and produces shots in a 170-degree radius - Your subject is captured in a fun, compact circle in each 35mm print. I worked on the creative direction, concept and product design management; including product, packaging, book design, add-on materials and worldwide online, retail and wholesale launches. The Japan Golden Week edition cameras, including its packaging, are a product of the Lomographic Society International. They have been developed by the in-house design team.
item.content:encoded: When conceived, these cameras were meant to commemorate Japan's Golden Week, a time for celebrating Japanese culture and taking a well-earned rest from work. After the natural disasters of 2011, the cameras were taken on a whole new meaning; they became a way to help the community to recover from the damages caused by the earthquake and tsunami. With the purchase of a camera, you were contributing to the donation of EUR 20,000 to the Red Cross Relief Japan campaign. The inspiration for this edition were the Japanese tenuguis and vintage Kimonos. Taking their craftsmanship approach and immaculate textile print design, we chose a calm and light color to celebrate the welcoming of the spring. The graphics covering the camera bodies, were printed with metallic Pantone on natural raw canvas. We used the same fabric to bind the books and the same metallic tones for the front/end book papers. The Diana Mini "Jiyu" symbolizes freedom and has a delicate charm with its floral design and clean colours. It uses 35mm film and produces beautiful square or half-frame photos. The Diana F+ "Kirameki" sparkles with its intricate design and calming colours. This medium-format camera promises dreamy square photos and unlimited creative options when paired with Diana accessories. The Fisheye 2 "Shiawase" symbolizes the spreading of happiness and produces shots in a 170-degree radius - Your subject is captured in a fun, compact circle in each 35mm print. I worked on the creative direction, concept and product design management; including product, packaging, book design, add-on materials and worldwide online, retail and wholesale launches. The Japan Golden Week edition cameras, including its packaging, are a product of the Lomographic Society International. They have been developed by the in-house design team.

item.title: Brooklyn Museum
item.description: Working in conjunction with a major architectural renovation and addition by Polshek Partnership, we redesigned the public face of the Brooklyn Museum. Our solution imagines the Brooklyn Museum as an alternative museum: family- rather than tourist-oriented, turning to its immediate community. The new logo is a contemporary take on the classic museum seal. The new seal changes and mutates, depending on its usage, to indicate the wide range of the Museum's collection, and their changing and dynamic programs. The concept carries through to their advertising campaign, print materials, and retail packaging, and outwardly to the comprehensive signage system in the lobby, admission, and exterior areas of the museum.
item.content:encoded: Working in conjunction with a major architectural renovation and addition by Polshek Partnership, we redesigned the public face of the Brooklyn Museum. Our solution imagines the Brooklyn Museum as an alternative museum: family- rather than tourist-oriented, turning to its immediate community. The new logo is a contemporary take on the classic museum seal. The new seal changes and mutates, depending on its usage, to indicate the wide range of the Museum's collection, and their changing and dynamic programs. The concept carries through to their advertising campaign, print materials, and retail packaging, and outwardly to the comprehensive signage system in the lobby, admission, and exterior areas of the museum.

item.title: The Happy Film Titles
item.description: We started a documentary movie about happiness, called the Happy Film. Its a proper look at all the strategies serious psychologists recommend that improve wellbeing, they include Meditation, cognitive therapy and psychological drugs. I will try them all out and report back on the results. The film will be visually driven and will be released it in theaters in fall 2013.
item.content:encoded: We started a documentary movie about happiness, called the Happy Film. Its a proper look at all the strategies serious psychologists recommend that improve wellbeing, they include Meditation, cognitive therapy and psychological drugs. I will try them all out and report back on the results. The film will be visually driven and will be released it in theaters in fall 2013.

item.title: From Cologne with love
item.description: From Cologne with love Once in a while it happens that we have to send real mail out into the world. «From Cologne with love» is our brandnew set of goodies, which we created to enjoy our clients and friends who receive mail from us, ourselves and - not to forget - the postman. So we did a whole range of different sticky things to put on envelopes and parcels: different sized address-labels, stickers, tape and stamps (not sticky). All of these goodies can be combined however you like! Want Mail from us? Write us! ARE WE DESIGNER Luxemburger Strasse 55 D-50674 Köln
item.content:encoded: From Cologne with love Once in a while it happens that we have to send real mail out into the world. «From Cologne with love» is our brandnew set of goodies, which we created to enjoy our clients and friends who receive mail from us, ourselves and - not to forget - the postman. So we did a whole range of different sticky things to put on envelopes and parcels: different sized address-labels, stickers, tape and stamps (not sticky). All of these goodies can be combined however you like! Want Mail from us? Write us! ARE WE DESIGNER Luxemburger Strasse 55 D-50674 Köln

item.title: Folio.
item.description: Identity & Editorial Design for a quarterly design journal based in Monterrey & Mexico City. Folio was conceived with the idea of developing a container for design topics, that doesn't contaminate the design itself or the content. Face started from the naming, creating a generic, easy to remeber, simple and appealing name that makes sense not only for the type of document, but also for keeping track of the issue with the number or folio. The design was the easy part. A very bold, legible, simple logo to communicate good design. Add some stylish and generic fonts to the mix and you can call it a win instantly. The layout is based on technical documents where everything is self explanatory, even literal by naming every space, item, element or text by its name. The overlapping of photos creates a more appealing, aesthetic look. Overall this simple document contains and documents what's best for everybody: good content inside a good container.
item.content:encoded: Identity & Editorial Design for a quarterly design journal based in Monterrey & Mexico City. Folio was conceived with the idea of developing a container for design topics, that doesn't contaminate the design itself or the content. Face started from the naming, creating a generic, easy to remeber, simple and appealing name that makes sense not only for the type of document, but also for keeping track of the issue with the number or folio. The design was the easy part. A very bold, legible, simple logo to communicate good design. Add some stylish and generic fonts to the mix and you can call it a win instantly. The layout is based on technical documents where everything is self explanatory, even literal by naming every space, item, element or text by its name. The overlapping of photos creates a more appealing, aesthetic look. Overall this simple document contains and documents what's best for everybody: good content inside a good container.

item.title: Avund Goods
item.description: ? | Minimal leather goods company combining the accuracy of modern technology with the feel of traditional crafts. Avund Goods was created in 2012 by Mika Becktor and Tom Hayes, two graduates from the Savannah College of Art and Design. One Industrial Designer from Sweden and one Graphic Designer from England who wanted to join forces and bring their passions to life. Our mission is to create minimal and functional things, designed for the consumer who appreciates hand made quality, and products that are meticulously thought out.
item.content:encoded: ? | Minimal leather goods company combining the accuracy of modern technology with the feel of traditional crafts. Avund Goods was created in 2012 by Mika Becktor and Tom Hayes, two graduates from the Savannah College of Art and Design. One Industrial Designer from Sweden and one Graphic Designer from England who wanted to join forces and bring their passions to life. Our mission is to create minimal and functional things, designed for the consumer who appreciates hand made quality, and products that are meticulously thought out.

item.title: Insidehook
item.description: Create a brand identity and email design for Inside Hook, building an editorial platform for men 35 - 55 that stands out among the thousands of emails they receive to become an essential part of their day. In developing Inside Hook's brand identity, we were inspired by the idea of a solution that looks, feels and functions like something one would carry with him, referencing a journal or a trusted publication. As we've learned from our experience working on successful daily email platforms, it's crucial to create a brand that will maintain a sense of fun and intrigue even after many repeat viewings. In other words, we set out to design a branded email that people will want to open every day. The logo typeface is bold, masculine and modern with a hint of history. Brackets built from the oo's in "Hook" house changing icons for each category, to keep design fresh and indicate content. Icons were chosen to be descriptive while providing some wit and discovery to each email.
item.content:encoded: Create a brand identity and email design for Inside Hook, building an editorial platform for men 35 - 55 that stands out among the thousands of emails they receive to become an essential part of their day. In developing Inside Hook's brand identity, we were inspired by the idea of a solution that looks, feels and functions like something one would carry with him, referencing a journal or a trusted publication. As we've learned from our experience working on successful daily email platforms, it's crucial to create a brand that will maintain a sense of fun and intrigue even after many repeat viewings. In other words, we set out to design a branded email that people will want to open every day. The logo typeface is bold, masculine and modern with a hint of history. Brackets built from the oo's in "Hook" house changing icons for each category, to keep design fresh and indicate content. Icons were chosen to be descriptive while providing some wit and discovery to each email.

item.title: OBRAS MAESTRAS (MASTERPIECES)
item.description: La Fábricas Obras Maestras (Masterpieces) is a deluxe edition collection of large format monographic books that offer a thorough analysis on the life and work of the most important Spanish contemporary photographers. The collection, which was created in 2009, comes out every six months.
item.content:encoded: La Fábricas Obras Maestras (Masterpieces) is a deluxe edition collection of large format monographic books that offer a thorough analysis on the life and work of the most important Spanish contemporary photographers. The collection, which was created in 2009, comes out every six months.
